questions.text: 1. Obesity and overweight are linked to several cancers. The risk of which of these is not increased with obesity or overweight?
questions.solution:
The risk of meningioma is not increased with obesity or overweight.

Meningiomas are usually benign, slow-growing, smaller lesions, usually detected incidentally in an elderly patient. They arise from the meninges. If the lesion is large or positioned to impinge on main structures, the patient may require steroids and early surgery.

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: Stomach cancer, especially proximal stomach cancer,  multiple myeloma, and pancreatic cancer can occur due to obesity and being overweight.

questions.text: 2. Which of the following is not a boundary of the hepato-cystic triangle?
questions.solution:
Cystic artery is not a boundary of the hepato-cystic triangle.

The boundaries of hepatocystic triangle are: (Mnemonic: LHC)

* Superior boundary: Inferior surface of Liver

* Medial boundary: Common Hepatic duct

* Lateral boundary: Cystic duct

It is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within its boundaries. The cystic lymph node often lies superfcial to the cystic artery and acts as a landmark to locate this artery in diffcult cases.

questions.text: 3. A child is planned for cleft lip surgery. Which of the following muscle is first repaired?
questions.solution:
Orbicularis oris is the first muscle that is repaired in cleft lip surgery. 

A cleft lip is characterized by a partial or complete lack of circumferential continuity of the lip. The deformity involves the mucosa, orbicularis oris muscle, and skin. Hence, continuity of the orbicularis oris muscle is disrupted in babies born with a cleft lip. 

The main aim of cleft surgery is muscle reconstruction to correct the underlying anatomical abnormalities that can lead to issues with appearance and function. Cleft lip repair is performed between 3 and 6 months of age. Millard cleft lip repair is done by downward rotation of the medial portion of the lip and advancement of the lateral portion into the defect created by the rotation. It involves detachment of the orbicularis oris muscle’s abnormal attachments and creating a horizontal bridge across the cleft to form a complete sphincter around the mouth. Hence the first muscle that is repaired in cleft lip surgery is orbicularis oris. 

The image below shows the rotation-advancement procedure of Millard cleft lip repair. Flap A is moved between B and C, C is rotated slightly while B is pushed down to create the cupid's bow.

questions.text:
4. Which of the following is correct regarding nerve grafts?

* Nerve grafting is used for peripheral nerves

* It is used for the surgical repair of facial nerve palsy

* Most common nerves are saphenous nerve and anterior interosseous nerve

* Nerve graft can be reconstructed only with fibrin glue
questions.solution:
Statement 1 and 2 are correct about nerve grafts.

Nerve grafts are used to reconstruct peripheral nerves including the brachial plexus (Statement 1). 

It is also used in the surgical management of facial palsy by utilising a cross-facial nerve graft (Statement 2).  It can also be used for managing corneal paraesthesia.

Common donor nerves include the sural nerve, medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve and the sensory branch of the posterior interosseous nerve, and not saphenous nerve and anterior interosseous nerve (Statement 3).

Whereas vessels are anastomosed, nerves are approximated typically using epineurial sutures with or without fibrin glue in a tension-free manner. Only fibrin glue is not adequate for nerve reconstruction (Statement 4).

questions.text: 5. A 65 year old female presents with recent-onset constipation and blood in stools. She reports a history of altered bowel habits. Colonoscopy reveals a superficial lesion located 6 cm from the anal verge. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosal layer of the colon, with no evidence of invasion and no lymph node involvement. What is the TNM staging of the tumor?
questions.solution:
The TNM staging of the described tumor is Stage 0. 

According to the TNM classification, the tumor is confined to mucosa, i.e., not invading the submucosa. Hence it can be classified as Tis (Tumor in situ). There is no regional lymph node involvement, hence N0 and no distant metastasis, hence M0. So the TNM classification is Tis N0 M0. According to the AJCC staging, Tis N0 M0 corresponds to Stage 0. 

Other options

Stage T N M
Stage 1 T1, T2 N0 M0
Stage 2A T3 N0 M0
Stage 2B T4a N0 M0

questions.text:
6. Which among the following are incorrect about tension pneumothorax?

* Occurs due to improper dressing of open wound

* Blunt trauma with simple pneumothorax can never convert to tension pneumothorax

* The single most common cause is due to positive pressure in mechanical ventilation 

* Can be caused due to spinal injury
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are incorrect about tension pneumothorax. 

A tension pneumothorax develops when a ‘one-way valve’ air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the afected lung. Common causes of tension pneumothorax are penetrating chest trauma, blunt chest trauma with a parenchymal lung injury and air leak that did not spontaneously close, iatrogenic lung injury (e.g. due to central venepuncture) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation. 

If an open pneumothorax is improperly dressed (e.g., complete occlusion of the chest wall defect without a tube thoracostomy) it may convert into a tension pneumothorax (Statement 1).

A simple pneumothorax from blunt trauma can progress to a tension pneumothorax, especially if untreated or if on positive pressure ventilation (Statement 2).

Positive pressure in mechanical ventilation is a common cause of tension pneumothorax since it can cause elevation in the trans-alveolar pressure which results in alveolar rupture and leakage of air into the extra-alveolar tissue, but it is not the single most common cause of tension pneumothorax (Statement 3). 

Tension pneumothorax is a rare and life-threatening complication that can be caused due to spinal injury (Statement 4).

questions.text: 7. Which of the following is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Achalasia - Los angeles score is the incorrect pair. Los angeles score is for reflux esophagitis, and not achalasia. 

According to the Los Angeles classifcation, reflux esophagitis can be graded as:

 Grade A One (or more) mucosal breaks no longer than 5 mm that do not extend between the tops of the two mucosal folds
Grade B One (or more) mucosal breaks longer than 5 mm that do not extend between the tops of two mucosal folds
Grade C Mucosal breaks that are continuous between the tops of two or more mucosal folds but that involve less than 75% of the circumference
Grade D Mucosal break that involves at least 75% of the oesophageal circumference


Other options: 

Option A: The M-ANNHEIM multiple risk factor classification system is a simple and objective classification for chronic pancreatitis. It allows patients to be categorized according to the etiology, clinical stage, and severity of their disease. 

Option C: Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) is a 10-point scale for assessing bowel preparation after all cleansing maneuvers are completed before a colonscopy. 

Option D: The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. Based on the principle that parathyroid hormone (PTH) has a half-life of 3–5 minutes, the criteria state that in single-gland disease, PTH levels should fall to the normal range and decrease by more than 50% from the highest preoperative value within 10 minutes of gland removal.

The given image shows SADI-S. 

Single-anastomosis duodenoileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) is a newer bariatric surgical technique derived from the biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS). It involves performing a sleeve gastrectomy followed by creating an end-to-side duodenoileal anastomosis. The common channel–alimentary limb is typically 250–300 cm in length. This approach offers several benefits, such as retaining the pylorus, avoiding a second anastomosis compared to the traditional duodenal switch, and potentially shortening the operation time and lowering the risk of complications during surgery



Other options:

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery. In this procedure, the pylorus is intact and the pressure in the stomach increases leading to increased chances of reflux. Patients can develop gastroesophageal reflux disease and Barrett's oesophagus as a long-term complication. There is also a risk of becoming obese again in sleeve gastrectomy. Short-term complications include a staple leak at an angle of His, intra-abdominal bleed, and DVT/PE. The staple leak at an angle of his can present up to 30 days after the surgery and can cause sepsis. Urgent CT scans with re-laparoscopy are indicated in such cases.

questions.text:
9. Which of the following statements are correct about negative pressure dressing?

* Decreases bacterial load 

* Pressure of -125 mm Hg used

* Reduces edema and forms more granulation tissue

* Dressing can be done after 5-7 days

* Used continuosly or intermittently
questions.solution:
All the statements (1, 2, 3, 4 and 5) are correct about negative pressure dressing. 

Negative pressure dressing, also called as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), uses intermittent or continuous topical negative pressure (up to –125 mmHg) through a sealed foam dressing in order to stimulate the formation of granulation tissue, reduce local oedema and tissue exudate and reduce bacterial load. It is used as a dressing to secure a skin graft to its recipient bed, temporary coverage of a complex acute wound (e.g. an open abdomen) until definitive cover can be achieved or to manage chronic wounds such as pressure ulcers. It is not recommended in the setting of exposed vessels, malignancy, untreated osteomyelitis, necrotic tissue or non-enteric and unexplored fstulae. 

Method of VAC application includes thorough debridement, adequate haemostasis and application of sterile foams dressing. A fenestrated tube is embedded in the foam and the wound is sealed with adhesive tape to make it airtight. The fenestrated tube is connected to a vacuum pump with a fluid collection container. The image given below shows negative-pressure wound therapy to promote wound healing in an open abdomen.



Frequent dressing changes during negative-pressure wound therapy are costly and cause patient discomfort. Hence a 5-7 days interval between changes of the dressing is acceptable depending on clinical assessment.

questions.text: 10. The term Z- plasty refers to
questions.solution:
The term Z- plasty refers to flap transposition and lengthening scar

Z-plasty is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotation flaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. In this technique, two flaps are rotated, each into the donor site of the other, to rearrange the tissues in a way that redirects the lines of tension and lengthens the central limb. It is best used in releasing simple contractures.

Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Two triangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in the length of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound.

Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening and realignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoided because the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of the wound difficult. 

Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarring tendencies.

questions.text: 11. A young male presented to triage after an RTA, with a GCS 8/15. On examination, patient was unconscious, has absent breath sounds on the right side, is hypotensive with SBP 90 mm Hg and has an SpO₂ of 85%. What is the sequence of management?

choices.text: Secure airway, insert ICD and administer IV fluids
Take history, administer dextrose, and perform  eFAST
Perform CT- brain, then secure airway

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability, decreased oxygen saturation (85%), GCS of 8/15 and absent breath sounds on the right side of the chest, with a history of a road traffic accident are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The next step of management in this case is to secure the airway, insert ICD and administer IV fluids

According to the latest ATLS guidelines, the order of primary survey in a trauma patient is ABCDE, identify life-threatening conditions:  

* Airway with cervical spine protection

* Breathing 

* Circulation with control of haemorrhage

* Disability(neurological status)

* Exposure to assess for other injuries and environmental 

This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8, which indicates a severely altered level of consciousness. As per ATLS, patients with severe head injuries who have an altered level of consciousness or a GCS score of 8 or lower usually require the placement of a definitive airway i.e., cuffed, secured tube in the trachea. Therefore, securing the airway is the first priority, with care taken to restrict cervical spine motion due to the mechanism of injury (road traffic accident).

After securing the airway, breathing can be assessed. The patient’s oxygen saturation of 85%, and absent breath sounds on the right side strongly suggests tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confrmation. Treatment consists of immediate decompression by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula into the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line of the affected side, followed by insertion of a chest tube through the fifth intercostal space in the anterior axillary line. However, current teaching advocates undertaking decompression in the triangle of safety as shown in the image below:



Once the airway and breathing are secured, hemodynamic instability must be corrected by securing two large-bore peripheral venous catheters to maintain circulation. Other investigations, such as NCCT head and CT head, are done later on during further evaluation in the secondary survey.

questions.text: 12. Which of the following is the most common colloid used in the Muir and Barclay formula?
questions.solution:
The common colloid used in Muir and Barclay formula is albumin. 

The original Muir and Barclay formula utilised fresh-frozen plasma as the colloid of choice, but now the most commonly used colloid is human albumin solution.

The most commonly used colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula:

* 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion

* A total of six portions are given in 36 hours 

* Three portions: One portion for every 4 hours in 12 hours.

* Two portions: One portion for every 6 hours in the next 12 hours.

* One portion: Remaining one portion in the last 12 hours.

Albumin should be preferably administered after the frst 12 hours post burn as the massive fuid shifts drive proteins out of the cells. Plasma proteins are responsible for inward oncotic pressure that counteracts the outward capillary hydrostatic pressure. Parkland formula and Evan's formula are used to calculate the crystalloid volume to be given in the first 24 hours.

questions.text: 13. In a chronic limb ischemia patient, what is the ABPI below which it can cause imminent gangrene?
questions.solution:
In a chronic limb ischemia patient, ABPI (Ankle-brachial Pressure Index) below 0.3 can cause imminent gangrene.

The Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of the systolic blood pressure at the ankle to that in the arm. The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator. It is used to assess patients who may be at risk for cardiovascular events. To measure it: 

* Blood pressure is taken in both upper limbs, and the highest systolic reading is used as the reference (denominator)

* An ankle cuff is placed just above the ankle to measure blood flow in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries

* A pencil doppler probe is used to detect the return of blood flow in each artery

* The systolic pressure from each ankle artery is divided by the highest arm systolic pressure to calculate the ABPI for both arteries

ABPI values can be clinically interpreted as:

* Between 0.5 and 0.7 is typically seen in patients with claudication.

* Between 0.3 and 0.5 is associated with rest pain.

* Below 0.3 is seen in patients with gangrene.

These values can vary depending on how compressible the vessels are and may be less reliable in individuals with heavily calcified arteries.

questions.text: 14. What is the Alvarado score for a patient presenting with fever, nausea, migratory right lower quadrant pain, rebound tenderness, and a white blood cell count greater than 14,000 cells/mm³?
questions.solution:
The Alvarado (MANTRELS) score for this patient is 6:

* Migratory right iliac fossa pain - 1

* Anorexia - 0 (Absent)

* Nausea / vomiting - 1

* Tenderness in right iliac fossa - 0 (Absent)

* Rebound tenderness - 1

* Elevated temperature - 1

* WBC count > 14,000 cells/mm i.e. Leukocytosis - 2

* Shift to the left of neutrophils - 0 (Absent)

Several clinical and laboratory-based scoring systems have been devised to assist in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis. The most widely used is the Alvarado (MANTRELS) score.

Pearl PM1317: Alvarado Scoring System

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: 15. Stage T4b breast cancer includes all except
questions.solution:
Erythema > 1/3rd of the breast surface is not included under Stage T4b. 

According to the TNM staging criteria, T4b includes any of the following skin changes:

* Ulceration of the overlying skin (Option D)

* Macroscopic satellite nodules on the ipsilateral breast skin (Option C)

* Oedema of the skin, including peau d’orange (Option B)

Peau d’orange (image below) refers to a dimpled appearance of the skin resembling an orange peel. It results from obstruction of the subdermal lymphatics by tumor cells or by infiltration from axillary lymph nodes. It is a classic sign of locally advanced breast cancer and is included under T4b.



Diffuse erythema involving more than 1/3rd of the breast surface is characteristic of T4d that is inflammatory carcinoma, not T4b.

questions.text: 16. The following approach is used in
questions.solution:
The approach shown in the given image is used for correcting dog ear. 

Occasionally, ‘dog ears’ remain in the corner of elliptical incisions despite adequate care having been taken during the formation and primary closure of an elliptical wound. In these situations, it is advisable to pick up the ‘dog ear’ with a skin hook and excise it as shown in the image. This allows for a satisfactory cosmetic outcome.



Other options: 

Option A: Keloid excision can be done secondarily as an adjuvant to silicone gel, intralesional corticosteroids, radiotherapy or aternative therapies with bleomycin and mitomycin C. The given image shows a keloid which is an excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site with growth of the scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound.



Option B: Abscess drainage is initially attempted by needle aspiration. Surgical incision and drainage should be reserved for abscesses that do not resolve after aspiration and treatment with antibiotics. An incision is made directly over the center of the abscess until pus is expressed. The incision should be made parallel to skin tension lines in order to prevent scar tissue formation. After the abscess is drained, the wound should be copiously irrigated with sterile normal saline solution. The image shows an 11-size blade that is used:



Option D: Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ) is a partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. It is harvested with the help of a Humby knife, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: 17. Breast conservation surgery not contraindicated in

choices.text: Previous history of radiation to chest
Persistent positive margins even after resection

questions.solution:
Breast conservation surgery is not contraindicated in tumor involving single quadrant. In fact, a tumor involving only one quadrant allows for adequate excision with clean margins while still maintaining a good cosmetic outcome. 

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) involves removing the tumor along with a 1-cm margin of healthy breast tissue, aiming to preserve most of the breast. It is done in patients whose tumors are localized (usually in a single quadrant), with no multicentric disease, and who can undergo postoperative radiotherapy. After surgery, patients receive radiotherapy to reduce the risk of local recurrence. This combination is called breast conservation therapy (BCT).

Other options:

Option A: BCS requires radiotherapy after surgery. Previous history of radiation limits the ability to safely give more radiation, so BCS is contraindicated.

Option C: Scleroderma and other connective tissue diseases increase the risk of severe radiation reactions, making BCS risky.

Option D: Persistent positive margins after resection that is if cancer cells remain even after attempts to clear margins, BCS is not advisable because complete removal of tumor is essential.

Pearl PM0884: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

* 1st-trimester pregnancy

* Diffuse microcalcifications

* Persistently positive pathologic margin

* Multicentric tumor

Relative contraindications:

* Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis

* Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast

* Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex

* Multifocal tumor

* History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.
